thread.title_full: US dominates Puerto Rico to capture World Baseball Classic | New York Post

author: Ryan Lazo
title: US dominates Puerto Rico to capture World Baseball Classic
text:
Five days ago, Marcus Stroman stood no chance against Puerto Rico in the second round of the World Baseball Classic.
In the championship game Wednesday night, however, Stroman delivered a different story.
The Long Island native flummoxed the same lineup he previously could not solve, tossing six-plus innings of one-hit ball, while Ian Kinsler and the United States’ offense did the rest in a dominating 8-0 win at Dodger Stadium in Los Angeles over a Puerto Rico squad that entered the final undefeated.
The victory marked the first time the U.S. has won the World Baseball Classic in the team’s first trip to the championship game in four editions of the event.
With Stroman on the hill, the U.S. wasn’t going to be denied. The 5-foot-8 flamethrower showed why he’s the Blue Jays’ No. 1 starter from the opening pitch, locating all of his deliveries with the precision of an artist. His power sinkers darted across the corners of the paint, while his late-breaking slider made others look downright silly as he picked up three strikeouts. He allowed just two baserunners, a leadoff walk to Carlos Beltran in the second inning, and a leadoff double by Angel Pagan in the seventh.
Meanwhile, the U.S. offense had no such problems.
Your browser does not support iframes. After falling prey to Mets right-hander Seth Lugo’s sharp-breaking curveball through the first few innings — he racked up seven strikeouts — they adjusted. Kinsler, who spoke out against the energetic play of Puerto Rico and the Dominican Republic on Tuesday, let his bat do the talking in the final, blasting a two-run homer in the third inning and jump-starting a rally in the fifth.
The Tigers’ second baseman opened the frame with a line-drive single to left before Christian Yelich and Andrew McCutchen each followed with run-scoring singles to give the U.S. breathing room.
Two innings later, they blew the game wide open.
Brandon Crawford lined a two-run single into shallow right, and Giancarlo Stanton added an RBI single off of Jose Berrios to end any threat of the tension and late-game drama that has engulfed the tournament over the past few weeks.
When the final out was recorded, catcher Jonathan Lucroy leapt out of his crouch, closer David Robertson pumped his fists in the air, and a dog pile formed in the middle of the diamond with Stroman in the middle of it.
Just the way Stroman imagined it.
